https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/09/opini.abstract: Download interview with Margrethe Vestager, European Union's commissioner for competition, who offers recommendations for books and other forms of entertainment.

headline.main: Margrethe Vestager
headline.print_headline: Margrethe Vestager

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/16/trave.snippet: With new services like Bandwagon and Tripda, and others expanding, there are more ways than ever to hire a car or share a ride in many cities.

headline.main: Need a Taxi to the Airport? Options Expanding Beyond Uber
headline.print_headline: Need a Ride? Your Options Are Growing

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/07/fashi.snippet: An entrepreneur turns to his techie roots to start a site for collectors of analog watches.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/07/fashi.abstract: Former Silicon Valley entrepreneur Kevin Rose partners with Benjamin Clymer to launch Hodinkee Inc, Nolita-based online service providing watch collectors and enthusiasts with social networking, sale opportunities, and provenance-verifying tools.

headline.main: A Facebook for Watch Geeks
headline.print_headline: A Facebook for Watch Geeks

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/busin.snippet: The company said it was offering unlimited leave for new mothers and fathers for one year after the birth or adoption of a child.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/busin.abstract: Netflix initiates unlimited leave policy for new mothers and fathers in first year after birth or adoption of child, policy that is far more generous than what is offered at most large American corporations; employees will receive full pay under plan, as well as other benefits like part-time work upon return; company cites need to retain top talent.

headline.main: Netflix Offers Expanded Maternity and Paternity Leave
headline.print_headline: Netflix Offers Greater Leave for Parents

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/us/po.snippet: Republican campaigns are preparing to magnify their candidates’ onstage messages with social media offerings like prewritten, issue-specific Twitter posts.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/us/po.abstract: Presidential campaigns are working to hone social media strategy for their candidates, paying particular attention to marquee events like first Republican debate; social media platforms are also rolling out array of new tools that campaigns can use to reach voters or to try to influence news coverage.

headline.main: As Republicans Debate, Campaigns Will Serve Up Instant Spin Online
headline.print_headline: Like Candidate’s Point in Debate? Here It Comes Again on Social Media

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/techn.snippet: The investment of $500 million annually signals the importance of the so-called Internet of Things to the future of manufacturing.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/techn.abstract: General Electric plans to spend roughly $500 million to connect machine sensors to cloud computing centers, where data will be parsed for insights into performance, maintenance and supplies; ultimate goal is to create marketplace for manufacturers to buy software, akin to industrial app store; shift highlights rising importance of so-called Internet of Things.

headline.main: G.E. Plans App Store for Gears of Industry
headline.print_headline: G.E. Plans App Store for Gears of Industry

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/04/techn.snippet: A consortium including Audi, BMW Group and Daimler will acquire Here as technology and digital maps become an increasingly important part of the car industry’s future.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/04/techn.abstract: Nokia says it has sold its Here digital mapping unit to group of German automakers for 2.8 billion euros, or about $3 billion.

headline.main: German Carmakers Buy Nokia’s Here Mapping Unit for $3 Billion
headline.print_headline: German Automakers Team Up to Buy Nokia’s Digital Mapping Division for $3 Billion

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/08/us/nu.snippet: Like those in the Sisters of Life religious order, younger nuns tend to be more conservative, wear the habit and have a strong sense of a mission.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/08/us/nu.abstract: Mark Oppenheimer Beliefs column observes younger generation of nuns, who are far fewer in number than generation that preceded them, tend to be more conservative, particularly on issue of abortion; holds becoming nun in 2015 is, nonetheless, a radical act.

headline.main: Nuns of a New Generation Forge Their Own Path
headline.print_headline: Nuns of a New Generation Are Forging Their Own Path

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/pageo.snippet: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, August 6, 2015

headline.main: Corrections: August 6, 2015
headline.print_headline: Corrections

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/09/trave.snippet: Returning to our honeymoon destination for a family vacation was a little less romantic, and certainly less trippy.

headline.main: 20 Years After Honeymoon, a Return Trip to Amsterdam
headline.print_headline: After 20 Years, a Different Kind of Trip

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/07/arts/.snippet: The exhibition, a cultural deconstruction of cats’ enduring popularity, takes a high-minded look at anthropomorphism and a low-brow wallow through cheesy trends and bad puns.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/07/arts/.abstract: Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria opens visual art exhibition How Cats Took Over the Internet, whimsical display that nevertheless seriously examines how cats became so popular online.

headline.main: ‘How Cats Took Over the Internet’ at the Museum of the Moving Image
headline.print_headline: The Internet Tastes Better With Cat Hair

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/16/magaz.snippet: Travels with Vit Jedlicka, the would-be founding father of a libertarian paradise.

headline.main: Welcome to Liberland, the World’s Newest Country (Maybe)
headline.print_headline: Founder

https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/0.snippet: The new Siebel Energy Institute is backing research into the software needed to deliver the energy-saving promise of smart-grid technology.
https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/0.abstract: The new Siebel Energy Institute is backing research into the software needed to deliver the energy-saving promise of smart-grid technology.

headline.main: Siebel Institute Seeks to Make the Smart Grid Smarter

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/techn.snippet: What started as an employee recruitment campaign has become a social media movement with the goal of diversifying the tech industry.

headline.main: Woman Behind #ILookLikeAnEngineer Says Campaign Against Gender Stereotypes Is ‘Long Overdue’

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/fashi.snippet: There are ways to unplug that don’t require you to downgrade to a CD player. Here are a few suggestions.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/fashi.abstract: Nick Bilton Disruptions column offers simple tips on how to unplug while on vacation, such as putting your phone on airplane mode and turning off email and social media apps.

headline.main: How to Vacation Like It’s 1999
headline.print_headline: How to Vacation Like It’s 1999

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/09/trave.snippet: Gone are the days when tourists wander around clutching guidebooks with an index of handy phrases. Today there are more convenient ways to facilitate communication.

headline.main: Foreign Language Apps for Traveling Abroad
headline.print_headline: At a Loss for Words? These Language Apps Can Help

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/busin.snippet: A Montana company is selling recycled shipping containers as homes, with bedrooms, kitchens and living rooms.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/busin.abstract: Montainer is start-up aimed at 'tiny house' market segment, driven by people who want to live smaller, simpler and more environmentally sustainable lives.

headline.main: Moving Into a Shipping Container, but Staying Put
headline.print_headline: Moving Into a Shipping Container, but Staying Put

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/04/techn.snippet: Animated, looping images are experiencing a surge on mobile devices, growing an industry and providing textless messages for millions of users.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/04/techn.abstract: GIFs, animated images known as graphics interchange format, are becoming more popular through their use on mobile devices; enthusiasts say GIFs provide instant emotional impression that is far more effective than text; Tumblr and Imgur are testing ad models that include promotion of GIFs.

headline.main: For Mobile Messaging, GIFs Prove to Be Worth at Least a Thousand Words
headline.print_headline: The Tiny Moving Message

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/01/techn.snippet: Yahoo has acquired Polyvore, a social shopping site that lets users pick and share clothing ensembles — and purchase all items shown.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/01/techn.abstract: Yahoo announces agreement to buy social shopping site Polyvore for undisclosed price.

headline.main: Yahoo Buys Polyvore, a Site Focused on Shopping
headline.print_headline: Yahoo Buys Social Media Site Focused on Shopping

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/03/arts/.snippet: As part of this event, Jeremy Denk played Brahms’s left-hand arrangement of Bach’s Chaconne in D minor.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/03/arts/.abstract: Vivien Schweitzer reviews classical music concert, featuring performances by pianists Jeremy Denk and Alexei Lubimov,  at Lincoln Center as part of Mostly Mozart Festival.

headline.main: Review: Jeremy Denk in a Full-Blooded Performance at Mostly Mozart
headline.print_headline: Brahms With a Caveat, but Not That You Could Tell

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/02/arts/.snippet: The architect Thomas Heatherwick’s designs dazzle, but their costs have stirred debate over the role of private financing for public spaces.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/02/arts/.abstract: Work of Thomas Heatherwick is subject of Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Exhibition that will run through end of 2015; Heatherwick is polymath designer whose ambitious designs have made him choice for number of public design projects; his public works are often source of controversy, given their expense and question of whether public should have to pay for them.

headline.main: The Price of Thomas Heatherwick’s Imagination
headline.print_headline: A Designer’s Imagination, and Its Cost

https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/0.snippet: The Internet of Things presents daunting technical and policy challenges. But smarter farming, for example, shows its potential.
https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/0.abstract: The Internet of Things presents daunting technical and policy challenges. But smarter farming, for example, shows its potential.

headline.main: The Internet of Things and the Future of Farming

https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/0.snippet: Bradley Tusk, a former campaign manager for New York’s last mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, is starting Tusk Ventures, a political consulting firm geared toward helping start-ups work with — and in some cases, beat back — government regulators.
https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/0.abstract: Bradley Tusk, a former campaign manager for New York’s last mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, is starting Tusk Ventures, a political consulting firm geared toward helping start-ups work with — and in some cases, beat back — government regulators.

headline.main: Political Consultant for Uber to Advise Other Start-Ups
headline.print_headline: Political Adviser for Uber to Help Other Start-Ups

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/04/scien.snippet: A new Microsoft chatbot called Xiaoice has become something of a hit in China, with responses based on actual conversations culled from the Internet.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/04/scien.abstract: Artificial-intelligence software known as Xiaoice has rapidly become popular in China, where its ability to mimic human conversation provides comfort to many; interface, developed by Microsoft, represents both culmination of years of artificial intelligence research and direction it will take in future.

headline.main: For Sympathetic Ear, More Chinese Turn to Smartphone Program
headline.print_headline: Program Knows Just How You Feel

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/02/educa.snippet: The stuff you’ve been told all summer about the first year of college is well intentioned. But there’s a huge amount of misinformation out there. Here’s some of it.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/02/educa.abstract: Mother of three coeds offers practical advice for new college students compiled from traditional thinking and actual experience.

headline.main: The Real Skinny on Freshman Year
headline.print_headline: The Real Skinny

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/02/us/ba.snippet: A recent study recommended a variety of changes to the region’s convoluted network of transportation systems, but a uniform overhaul has been difficult to achieve.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/02/us/ba.abstract: Transportation policy experts in Bay Area are engaged in increasingly intense debate about region's patchwork public transportation system in which more than 20 operators are spread across 101 municipalities and nine counties; issues is of particular concern given higher housing costs in San Francisco, which have driven more people to move farther away from metropolitan hubs to find affordable housing.

headline.main: Bay Area’s Disjointed Public Transit Network Inspires a Call for Harmony
headline.print_headline: Bay Area’s Disjointed Public Transit Network Inspires a Call for Harmony

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/02/busin.snippet: The chief executive of Alexandria Real Estate Equities talks about the value of trying to let employees persuade you when you’re making decisions.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/02/busin.abstract: Adam Bryant Corner Office column features interview with Alexandria Real Estate Equities chief executive Joel S Marcus.

headline.main: Joel S. Marcus on Taking the Ego Out of Leading
headline.print_headline: Taking the Ego Out of Leading

https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/12/reale.snippet: The Golden 1 Center is the nexus for renovation and new construction that many hope will turn the capital’s downtown into a hot spot.
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/12/reale.abstract: Golden 1 Center, new home arena for NBA's Sacramento Kings, will boast four-block development, including a public plaza and luxury hotel, at total cost of some $1 billion; city's leaders hope development will be catalyst for period of economic revival in California's capital.

headline.main: Dreams of a Hip, High-Tech Sacramento Hinge on Kings’ New Home Court
headline.print_headline: Dreams for Sacramento Hinge on Kings’ New Court
